item.title: Covid: Masks to remain compulsory on London transport
item.description: Face coverings must be worn despite restrictions easing in England on 19 July, London's mayor says.

item.title: Price rises speed up again as economy unlocks
item.description: The inflation rate hit 2.5% in June, exceeding the Bank of England's target for a second month.

item.title: Ban online racist abusers from football matches - Labour
item.description: Labour wants the courts to be given new powers in a forthcoming bill to crackdown on online abusers.

item.title: Peter Falconio murder: Australian police renew appeal to find body
item.description: Australian police want to recover the remains of Peter Falconio, who was killed in the outback 20 years ago.

item.title: Islamic State children in Syria face a lifetime in prison
item.description: Foreign children whose parents supported IS are stuck in Syrian camps, a BBC investigation finds.

item.title: Covid-19: Face coverings on London transport and price rises speed up
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Wednesday morning.

item.title: UK public at risk from hostile state threats - MI5
item.description: The MI5 chief says people need to be as vigilant about covert state action as about terrorism.

item.title: Troubles legacy: Victims' concern over government statement
item.description: It is believed proposals involve a statute of limitations to end all Troubles-era prosecutions.

item.title: Prince Charles' warning over survival of small farms
item.description: If they go out of business it will "rip the heart out of the British countryside", he says.

item.title: Carry on flying, says government green plan
item.description: The policy has been ridiculed by environmentalists who say the government is putting too much faith in innovation.

item.title: Covid: Plans to be revealed for fewer rules in Wales
item.description: It is not expected all rules will go, or that Wales will move as quickly as England.

item.title: HMS Queen Elizabeth: Covid outbreak on Navy flagship
item.description: There have been around 100 cases on HMS Queen Elizabeth, the BBC has been told.

item.title: REvil: Ransomware gang websites disappear from internet
item.description: The REvil group has been blamed for cyber-attacks on hundreds of businesses worldwide.

item.title: The Papers: Kids 'defend Lions' and 'outrage' at foreign aid cut
item.description: Wednesday's papers report on the fallout after three England players were subjected to racist abuse.

item.title: Stalking incidents increase during pandemic
item.description: There has been a “significant increase” in stalking offences according to the UK police lead for stalking.

item.title: Ros Atkins on... the trouble at Wembley
item.description: Ros Atkins looks at how crowd problems at Wembley played out from Sunday morning until after the final of Euro 2020.

item.title: The woman giving toys a new life
item.description: Rebecca transforms people's old and unwanted dolls and then gives them away for free.

item.title: A pandemic constitutional in pictures
item.description: Paul Treacy looks back at the photographs he took recovering from "long Covid".

item.title: Siblings injured taking selfie as lightning struck
item.description: Rachel, Isobel and Andrew Jobson were injured as they took the photo during a thunderstorm.

item.title: Ex-Nissan boss Carlos Ghosn: How I escaped Japan in a box
item.description: The former boss of Nissan and Renault reveals how evaded house arrest to flee to Lebanon.

item.title: How the Met Police deals with London's missing person reports
item.description: The missing persons specialists at the Met Police deal with thousands of cases a year. How do they prioritise them?

item.title: Summer of Soul: New film revives lost 'Black Woodstock' gig series
item.description: Questlove's directorial debut uncovers lost gigs with Sly Stone, Stevie Wonder and Nina Simone.

item.title: A question of faith: Biden, Catholicism and the presidency
item.description: A debate over communion for the second Catholic US president renews questions of religion and politics.

item.title: What more can be done to stop racist abuse online?
item.description: Abuse directed at England footballers has prompted calls for more action to tackle hate online.

item.title: How serious is the shortage of HGV drivers?
item.description: The industry says there's a shortage of 100,000 drivers but why is that and what is the likely impact?

item.title: Khashoggi murder: US softens towards Saudi leader
item.description: Saudi Arabia's crown prince was shunned after the 2018 killing, but the kingdom is back in business.

item.title: I don't know when my next chance will come - watch highlights as Vince reflects on 'greatest moment' of career
item.description: James Vince says his first England century in victory over Pakistan in the third one-day international is the "best moment" of his career.

item.title: Rashford could miss two months of season due to shoulder operation
item.description: Manchester United striker Marcus Rashford could miss the first two months of the season after deciding to have surgery on a shoulder injury.

item.title: Irons off the tee and 32,000 daily fans - what to expect as The Open returns
item.description: The Open Championship is back after a two-year wait but what can we expect from the field at Royal St George's?

item.title: No Ronaldo, Pogba or Kane - but who did make your team of Euro 2020?
item.description: No Cristiano Ronaldo, no Paul Pogba, no Harry Kane, but which players did make your team of Euro 2020?

item.title: From broken back to Olympic medal favourite - meet GB shooter Coward-Holley
item.description: From a broken back to Team GB Olympic medal favourite, meet shooter Matthew Coward-Holley.

item.title: Johnson-Thompson steps up injury return - British Grand Prix highlights & report
item.description: Heptathlon world champion Katarina Johnson-Thompson continues her injury-shortened build-up to Tokyo with a sub-par 6.10m long jump at the British Grand Prix.

item.title: Marcus Rashford: Hundreds gather at mural for anti-racism demo
item.description: England star Marcus Rashford says an anti-racism demonstration at a mural of him left him "lost for words".

item.title: Covid rules: Is lockdown ending on 19 July?
item.description: Covid restrictions will ease again in both England and Scotland on 19 July.

item.title: Covid rules: How can the clinically vulnerable stay safe?
item.description: As social-distancing and other Covid rules end in England, how can people who were shielding stay safe?

item.title: What's the new guidance on face masks and coverings?
item.description: Face coverings are to remain in Scotland, while people in England won't have wear them after 19 July.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Vaccine passports: How can the NHS Covid Pass prove I've had both jabs?
item.description: Clubbers and people attending mass events in England could have to prove they've had both Covid jabs.

item.title: Covid: Should I be working from home or going back to the office?
item.description: The working from home advice in England is set to change on 19 July.

item.title: 'Indians don't talk about sex - so I help them'
item.description: An Indian sex coach says parents turn to her for advice as sex education is not available in schools.

item.title: Fire lookouts: The US Forest Service lookouts watching for fires
item.description: In remote towers, US Forest Service lookouts act as an early warning system for forest fires.

item.title: Virgin Galactic: Richard Branson's long, winding path to space
item.description: The BBC tracks the long, winding road to Sir Richard Branson's flight to the edge of space.

item.title: Bibaa and Nicole: The life after death of two sisters
item.description: Bibaa Henry and Nicole Smallman died in a senseless attack. But they should not be remembered as victims.

item.title: Why Canada is reforming indigenous foster care
item.description: The residential school legacy has been linked to the overrepresentation of indigenous children in care.
